Crimes.Crime_Name: Cessation of refugee protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's decision on cessation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.108(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants returned to Mexico with Mexican passports, creating a presumption of voluntary reavailment
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Voluntary return to Mexico with passports
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Voluntary reavailment of country of origin's protection
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Presumption of reavailment and ability to rebut
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of duress found insufficient to rebut presumption
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Use of Mexican passport, travel to Mexico
Crimes.Application_Basis: Voluntary reavailment through actions indicating reliance on home country protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Passport use and return to Mexico
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Continuation of refugee protection in Canada
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Under IRPA s.108(1)(a), refugee protection ceases upon voluntary reavailment

Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Loss of protected status in Canada
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicants voluntarily returned to Mexico after obtaining refugee status in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Presumption based on conduct; burden to rebut not met
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Lack of compelling evidence to counter official documentation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliance with conditions of protected person status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of RPD and Federal Court on cessation matters
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conduct interpreted as intentional re-engagement with home country protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Presumption of reavailment was not rebutted by credible evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient proof of duress or coercion
